title: Par 3 Golf Course | 2 of 2
question_text: Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved. In golf, par is determined by the number of strokes a golfer without advantage (or handicap, as it is termed) is expected to take on a given hole. The dot plots shown above are for two groups of golfers on a par $3$ course. The top dot plot is a summary of the total scores for $9\text{ holes}$ by $16$ inexperienced golfers, and the bottom dot plot is a summary of the total scores on the same course for $16$ experienced golfers. If the data for the two sets of golfers were combined and a new dot plot were created using the same scaling as the original two dot plots, then

choices.text: The combined dot plots distribution would have less variability than the distributions of the two original dot plots do separately.
The combined dot plot could provide information to the golf course manager about the relative difficulty of the course for inexperienced golfers.
The combined dot plot would have a shape that is roughly normal.
The combined dot plot would be skewed to the right.
The combined dot plot would have a median that is the mean of the medians of the original two dot plots.
